keyTakeAways: Black garden ants (Lasius niger) modify their nest architecture in response to a lethal fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum.
Infected ants self-isolate, and healthy ants (especially nurses) increase their distance from foragers, demonstrating proactive social distancing.
Nest structures become more compartmentalized, less interconnected, with farther-spaced entrances and longer travel routes, reducing disease transmission.
These architectural changes work in tandem with social behaviors to reduce epidemic spread, representing a form of 'architectural immunity'.
The findings provide the first documented case of a non-human social species actively modifying its environment to combat disease spread.
Scientists suggest that principles observed in ant colonies could inspire better human-designed public spaces to reduce disease transmission.

namedEntities.name: Metarhizium brunneum
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A common and lethal fungus that infects insects, including black garden ants, and transforms the host into a sporulating cadaver covered in infectious spores.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This pathogen is the key threat that drives the ants' adaptive responses in nest architecture and behavior, making it central to the study's focus on disease mitigation.

namedEntities.name: Lasius niger
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The black garden ant, a common species used in the study for its widespread presence and ease of study, particularly through mating flights in July.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This specific ant species is the subject of the research, demonstrating both social and architectural responses to fungal infection.

namedEntities.name: Nathalie Stroeymeyt
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A behavioral ecologist at the University of Bristol who led early research on how black garden ants respond socially to fungal infection.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She played a pivotal role in discovering the social distancing behavior in ants and later expanded the study to include nest architecture modifications.

namedEntities.name: Luke Leckie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A systems biologist at Indiana University Bloomington who collaborated with Stroeymeyt to investigate how ants alter nest structure in response to pathogens.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He led the structural analysis using CT scans and simulations to demonstrate that ants modify nest architecture to reduce disease spread.

namedEntities.name: Sarah Kocher
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An evolutionary biologist at Princeton University not involved in the study, who commented on the broader implications of the research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She highlighted the potential application of ant social immunity to human architectural design to prevent disease spread.

namedEntities.name: Science (journal)

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as the formal platform for the peer-reviewed publication of the key research findings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Black garden ants (Lasius niger) exhibit both social and architectural behaviors to combat a lethal fungal pathogen, Metarhizium brunneum. When infected, ants self-isolate and healthy ants—particularly nurses—increase their distance from foragers, showing proactive social distancing. Further research revealed that infected colonies modify their nest structures to become more compartmentalized, with longer travel routes and farther-spaced entrances, reducing interactions and slowing disease transmission. This combination of social and structural adaptations represents a form of 'architectural immunity' and is the first documented case of a non-human species actively altering its environment to combat disease. Scientists believe these findings could inspire new strategies for designing public spaces to reduce disease spread, suggesting that human architecture might learn from ant colonies to balance protection and functionality.
title: Ants Design Nests to Reduce Disease Spread — A Blueprint for Human Architecture?
